👨‍💻 2020 Web Development Guide 👨‍💻

Preface

Web Development has come a long way from it's inception in the early 90's. Technologies have come and gone. Features that were once major programming problems to implement are now easily solved and abstracted away. As our tools for building become more powerful so do the demands of user experience. One simple HTML web pages have become sprawling web applications loaded with media, data transactions, user interactions, animations, and more as we head into the future.

So what's the problem? Go create a website 🤣.

For a noobie jumping into the Web Development scene there are a ton of web guides and tutorials out there on the Web already. Many are dated, highly opinionated, and use the same trivial examples. Others are too abstract and assumptious about what the reader knows. At this point there are too many sources out there, some of which can lead you down a rabbit hole of legacy code and misinformation.

This guide takes a direct path towards Web Development truth as of 2020. If you follow it you will soon be pumping out modern, clean, and smooth websites to drive your business or passion. Learning starts from the ground up using only the latest web development tools and best practices.

So go ahead and give the 2020 Web Developement Guide a shot!

{" "} I appreciate your desire to learn and would love to hear any feedback you have for me to improve this guide.



Thank you,



- Stefan_Bobrowski

2020 Web Development Guide

This guide aims to be as cross-platform and non-opinionated as possible but alas focuses on the following tools and technologies:

Programming

  • HTML - Structuring the Web
  • CSS - Styling the Web
  • Javascript - Dynamic client-side scripting
  • Node.js and NPM - Javascript runtime and package manager
  • React.js - Front-end Javascript framework

Downloads

  • VScode - Code Editor -{" "} Download
  • Node.js and NPM -{" "} Download {" "} (Don't need until Section VI)

The following web guide will take you from the basics of Web Development to it's mastery as of 2020. (Offical reference: MDN Web Docs )

Index

  • I. Intoduction
  • II. HTML
  • III. CSS
  • IV. Javascript
  • V. Putting it together like the Triforce
  • VI. Node.js, NPM, SCSS
  • VII. Going beyond: React Hooks

I. Introduction

{" "} The World Wide Web as we know it was envisioned in 1990 by Tim Berners-Lee. He had all of the tools necessary for a working Web: HyperText Transfer Protocol (HTTP), HyperText Markup Language (HTML), a Web Server, a Web Browser, and the first Web Page!

Why don't we create our first Web Page as Berner-Lee did.

Getting started

  • 1.) Download{" "} VScode
  • 2.) Create a file named 'index.html'.
  • 3.) Paste in the following code:

Welcome to my first Website!

    
See? Anyone can make their mark on the Worldwide Web.

  

`}

4.) Now open it in your web browser!

🌐 My First Website

My First Website

Welcome to my first Website!

See? Anyone can make their mark on the Worldwide Web.

    There it is our first website! However, this local website is not live on the World Wide Web. We have used our Web browser to open an HTML file from our local machine.

We could make this live by purchasing a domain and configuring a Web server ourselves such as Apache in the popular LAMP stack.

(There are many options when it comes to hosting your own website. In the end, it all boils down to copying your website files from your local computer to the Web Server. While this may sound simple, deployment is an extremely important step with many factors to consider that can quickly make it very complicated.)

For now let's assume anything we run locally will run exactly the same in the browser when hosted on a Web Server in the future.

Now, let's take our 'index.html' file from before and go over the HTML essentials line by line.

I. HTML

HTML Essentials

An HTML document is a plaintext document structured with elements. Elements are surrounded by matching opening and closing tags. Each tag begins and ends with angle brackets ( {"< >"})

Line 1: {""}{" "}

This line of code is the first thing a Web Browser reads and interprets when an HTML document is loaded. It tells the browser we are dealing with an HTML file.

This is a unique "tag" you only need once per html file. Historically this line has been a bit harder to remember. We thank HTML5 for the concise version.

Line 2: {""} is our first true HTML "tag". Tags are the names in our HTML document surrounded by chevrons {"< >"}{" "} that have a matching end-tag indicated by a backslash{" "} {"/"}. Our end-tag{" "} {""} is on Line 14.

The HTML tag is a mandatory wrapper for our HTML document.

Line 3 - 6: is the HEAD tag and it's contents. The head section is where we can set our site's TITLE, add META tags (containers for information about the site), and import stylesheets and scripts (more on that later).

Line 7: is our BODY tag. It is a wrapper for the body of our website and where we can start building the visual structure.

In this example we use a heading{" "} {"

"} tag and two paragraph {"

"} tags.

HTML Elements

Major HTML tags

  • div: generic container element
  • br: self-closing tag line break
  • span: generic container usually denoting a word or words with a special style{" "}
  • b: bold
  • i: italic
  • a: anchor tag. Used for links
  • p: paragraph tag element
  • h1: Header 1
  • h2
  • ul: unordered list
  • ol: ordered list
  • li: list item
  • img: image
  • video: video
  • table
  • td, tr
  • form
  • input
  • textarea
  • button
    • HTML5 semantic tags
  • nav
  • main
  • section
  • header
  • footer
